natural problem: If $p(t)$ and $q(t)$ are both seventh-degree polynomials in $t$, what is the degree of $p(t)\cdot q(t)$?
natural solution: The $t^7$ terms multiply to a $t^{14}$ term. All the other terms multiply to terms of lesser degree, so the degree of the product of polynomials is $\boxed{14}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and t :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. degree (p t) = 7"
and h1 : "\<forall> t. degree (q t) = 7"
shows  "degree (\<lambda> t. p t * q t) = 14"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 If $p(t)$ and $q(t)$ are both seventh-degree polynomials in $t$, what is the degree of $p(t)\cdot q(t)$? The final Answer is 14
 ### Proof
 The $t^7$ terms multiply to a $t^{14}$ term. All the other terms multiply to terms of lesser degree, so the degree of the product of polynomials is $\boxed{14}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and t :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. degree (p t) = 7"
and h1 : "\<forall> t. degree (q t) = 7"
shows  "degree (\<lambda> t. p t * q t) = 14"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given two functions, $p(t)$ and $q(t)$, where both have a polynomial degree of 7, find the degree of the product function $(p(t) \cdot q(t))$. The final answer is 14.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<exists>a b c d e f g h. \<forall>t. p t = a * t powr 7 + b * t powr 6 + c * t powr 5 + d * t powr 4 + e * t powr 3 + f * t powr 2 + g * t + h"
and h1 : "\<exists>i j k l m n o p. \<forall>t. q t = i * t powr 7 + j * t powr 6 + k * t powr 5 + l * t powr 4 + m * t powr 3 + n * t powr 2 + o * t + p"
shows  "\<exists>r s t u v w x y z a b c d e f g. \<forall>t. (p t) * (q t) = r * t powr 14 + s * t powr 13 + t * t powr 12 + u * t powr 11 + v * t powr 10 + w * t powr 9 + x * t powr 8 + y * t powr 7 + z * t powr 6 + a * t powr 5 + b * t powr 4 + c * t powr 3 + d * t powr 2 + e * t powr 1 + f * t powr 0"

 ### Proof

and h1 : "\<exists>i j k l m n o p. \<forall>t. q t = i * t powr 7 + j * t powr 6 + k * t powr 5 + l * t powr 4 + m * t powr 3 + n * t powr 2 + o * t + p"
shows  "\<exists>r s t u v w x y z a b c d e f g. \<forall>t. a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "degree (poly_lift p) = 7"
and h1 : "degree (poly_lift q) = 7"
shows  "degree (poly_lift (\<lambda>t. p t * q t)) = 14"

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<exists>k1. \<forall> t. p t = (\<Sum> i = 0..7. k1 i * t ^ i)"
and h1 : "\<exists>k2. \<forall> t. q t = (\<Sum> i = 0..7. k2 i * t ^ i)"
shows  "\<exists>k3. \<forall> t. (p t * q t) = (\<Sum> i = 0..14. k3 i * t ^ i)"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 If $p(t)$ and $q(t)$ are both seventh-degree polynomials in $t$, what is the degree of $p(t)\cdot q(t)$? The final Answer is 14
 ### Proof
 The $t^7$ terms multiply to a $t^{14}$ term. All the other terms multiply to terms of lesser degree, so the degree of the product of polynomials is $\boxed{14}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<exists>k1. \<forall> t. p t = (\<Sum> i = 0..7. k1 i * t ^ i)"
and h1 : "\<exists>k2. \<forall> t. q t = (\<Sum> i = 0..7. k2 i * t ^ i)"
shows  "\<exists>k3. \<forall> t. (p t * q t) = (\<Sum> i = 0..14. k3 i * t ^ i)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Given two polynomials $p(t)$ and $q(t)$, each of degree 7 with coefficients $k_1$ and $k_2$, respectively, find a polynomial of degree 14 with coefficients $k_3$ such that for every $t$, the product of $p(t)$ and $q(t)$ equals the polynomial with coefficients $k_3$.
